<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 813, 90]]<|/det|>
Some students investigate the transfer of thermal energy from a beaker of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 468, 106]]<|/det|>
They use the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 120, 890, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 341, 532, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 144, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 801, 390]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows the reading on the thermometer at the start of the investigation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 408, 544, 592]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 617, 534, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 648, 745, 667]]<|/det|>
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 677, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 677, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 581, 89]]<|/det|> A student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 878, 101]]<|/det|> He records the temperature of the water in beaker A and immediately starts a stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 920, 134]]<|/det|> The student records the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30 s. His readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 781, 166]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure for beaker B. Beaker B is fitted with a lid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 628, 197]]<|/det|> Complete the headings and the time column in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 212, 541, 228]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 242, 744, 483]]<|/det|>
beaker A
without a lid		beaker B
with a lid
\(t/\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {A}}/\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {B}}/\)
085.086.0
79.083.0
73.580.5
68.578.5
64.077.0
60.076.5
56.576.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 920, 499]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 146, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 920, 543]]<|/det|> Describe a precaution that should be taken to ensure that the temperature readings are as accurate as possible in this experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 588, 920, 606]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 146, 638]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 619, 180, 638]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 619, 813, 638]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating how using the lid affects the cooling of the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 774, 180, 792]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 774, 858, 792]]<|/det|> The temperature of the water in each beaker decreases during this investigation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 805, 900, 823]]<|/det|> Describe **one** other similarity in the pattern of the cooling of water in beakers A and B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 868, 920, 887]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water in beaker A. Use the values of \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) from Table 1.1 and the equation \(x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{(\theta_{0} - \theta_{180})}{T}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 125, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_0\) is the temperature of the water in beaker A at \(t = 0\), \(\theta_{180}\) is the temperature of the water at \(t = 180 \text{s}\), and \(T = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 171, 313, 189]]<|/det|>
Include a unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 233, 920, 252]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{\mathrm{A}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 265, 181, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 264, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water in beaker B. Use the values of \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) from Table 1.1 and the equation \(x_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{(\theta_{0} - \theta_{180})}{T}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 317, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_0\) is the temperature of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\), \(\theta_{180}\) is the temperature of the water at \(t = 180 \text{s}\), and \(T = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 395, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 426, 180, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 425, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
Thermal energy is transferred from the surface of the water and from the sides of the beaker during the investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 472, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that more thermal energy is transferred from the surface of the water than from the sides of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 518, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to your values of \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\), the average rate of cooling without a lid, and \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\), the average rate of cooling with a lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 580, 917, 599]]<|/det|>
statement ....................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 917, 630]]<|/det|>
justification ....................................................................................................................

<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 650, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 468, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 836, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the factors that affect the average speed of a ball falling in water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate the effect of **one** factor on the speed at which a ball of modelling clay falls in water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 584, 197]]<|/det|>
modelling clay that can be made into different sized balls

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 640, 212]]<|/det|>
metal ball bearings that can be embedded in the modelling clay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 470, 227]]<|/det|>
a long transparent tube, closed at one end

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 263, 243]]<|/det|>
a supply of water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 324, 274]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 495, 304]]<|/det|>
· state clearly the factor to be investigated

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 457, 336]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 515, 367]]<|/det|>
· state any key variables to be kept the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
· explain how to carry out the investigation, including the measurements to be made and any precautions that must be taken to ensure reliable results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 603, 444]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 576, 475]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
